I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to the People‘s Republic of Bangladesh for the Third Primary Education Development Project.1 

The  project  is  a  follow-on  to  the  ongoing  Second  Primary  Education  Development 
2. 
Program  (PEDP  II),  the  first  sector─wide  approach  (SWAp)  in  the  education  sector  in 
Bangladesh.  The  project  will  contribute  to  the  government‘s  5-year  (FY2012–FY2016)  Third 
Primary  Education  Development  Program  (PEDP  III)  covering  1  year  of  preprimary  education 
(PPE)  and  5  years  of  primary  education.  Together  with  eight  other  development  partners,  the 
project  will  support  the  government‘s  priorities  of  improving  student  learning  outcomes  and 
completion rates, and reducing disparities across regions. PEDP III will focus on achieving key 
output  results  and  other  implementation  steps  to  policy  and  institutional  changes  that  are 
essential to meet the government‘s objective of providing quality education for all children.2   

A. 

Rationale  

II. 

THE PROJECT 

1. 

Rationale for the Project 

 
 
3. 
Bangladesh  has  one  of  the  largest  primary  school  systems  in  the  world,  with  over 
16 million  children  enrolled  in  over  80,000  primary  schools.  Considerable  progress  has  been 
made in improving access to free and compulsory primary education. Gross enrollment rates in 
primary  education  improved  from  93.7%  in  2005  to  103.5%  in  2009,  and  net  enrollment  rates 
improved  from  87.2%  in  2005  to  93.9%  in  2009.  Bangladesh  was  one  of  the  few  countries  to 
achieve gender parity up to the secondary level by 2005. Despite significant progress in access 
to  education,  high  inefficiencies  persist—high  student  dropout  and  repetition  rates,  low 
completion,  and  high  student  and  teacher  absenteeism.  Two  rounds  of  national  student 
assessment indicate low student achievements in grades 3 and 5, but the results are improving.   
 
The  government  prepared  the  National  Education  Policy  (NEP)  to  address  the  above 
4. 
systemic issues in primary education.3 The NEP plans to (i) achieve education for all by 2015, 
and  (ii)  ensure  that  every  child  starts  primary  school  by  2011.  The  NEP  aims  at  reducing 
disparities between different types of schools, and expanding and improving primary education 
in disadvantaged locations in rural communities and urban slums. The major benefits foreseen 
are reduced repetition and dropout, improved completion rates, enhanced net enrolment rates, 
and  improved  transition  rates  to  secondary  education—all  as  a  result  of  improved  quality  and 
relevance of education in schools with initial input deficits. 
   
5. 
The ongoing PEDP II is jointly funded by the government and 11 development partners; 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  the  lead  development  partner.4 The  PEDP  II  largely 
contributed  to  improving  primary  education  participation  and  introducing  key  reforms.  It  has 
achieved  (i)  mainstreaming  minimum  service  standards  across  government  administered 
primary  schools through  the  primary  school quality  level  standards;  (ii)  a fair,  transparent,  and 
efficient  teacher  recruitment  system  for  government  primary  schools;  (iii)  the  introduction  of 
results-based  management  (RBM),  which  has  led  to  the  publication  of  the  annual  sector 
performance  report  that  helps  monitor  progress  on  key  performance  indicators  and  primary 
school  quality  level  standards;  (iv)  initiation  of  the  school  level  improvement  plans  (SLIPs)  to

participating  schools;  and  (v)  introduction  of  the  annual  grade  5  completion  examination  and 
implementation of the national student assessment every alternate year to assess progress on 
student achievements in grades 3 and 5. The PEDP II has also established a strong foundation 
for  a  SWAp  by  bringing  the  government  and  development  partners  together  for  the  first  time 
under  one  program  instead  of  separate  projects  funded  by  different  development  partners. 
Lessons  identified  from  the  PEDP  II  and  those  from  the  sector  assistance  performance 
evaluation5 are available in Appendix 2.6  
 
6. 
The  PEDP  III,  which  the  project  will  support,  will  build  on  the  PEDP  II  achievement, 
lessons  identified,  and  joint  experience  of  the  government  and  development  partners.  It  will 
(i) broaden the scope to include 1 year preprimary, and nonformal and second chance primary 
education; (ii) deepen quality improvement through improved teaching and learning practices in 
the classroom, including improved assessment; (iii) enhance school governance, accountability, 
and  community  mobilization;  (iv)  provide  targeted  support  to  disadvantaged  groups  and 
locations;  (v)  institutionalize  human  resource  development  to  incentivize  the  system  and 
enhance  capacity;  (vi)  deepen  and  institutionalize  an  RBM  and  monitoring  mechanism  at  all 
levels; (vii) target and ensure effective utilization of technical assistance (TA) at all levels within 
an  emerging  decentralization 
framework;  and  (viii)  enhance  subsector  management, 
coordination, and greater alignment with the country system.  
 
7. 
The  project  will  support  the  PEDP  III  with  a  project  lending  modality  since  (i) the 
interventions  are  more  of  an  investment  nature  and  incremental  steps  toward  reforms,  rather 
than structural policy reforms; and (ii) there is a need to ensure close oversight of the fiduciary 
environment,  so  it  is  not  suitable  for  the  use  of  program  lending.  However,  to  align  with  the 
salient  features  of  the  PEDP  III  under  a  SWAp,  the  project  has  incorporated  some  innovative 
features. 
 

Key Innovative Features of the Project  

2. 
The project has three innovative features that are explained in detail in Appendix 2.6  

8. 

(i) 

(ii) 

Greater  focus  on  results.  The  project  will  link  financing  to  the  government 
achieving  nine  annual  disbursement  linked  indicators  (DLIs)─output  level  results 
and  implementation  steps  to  policy  and  institutional  changes  that  are  deemed 
essential  to  meet  the  project‘s  objectives.  The  use  of  DLIs  will  help  Project 
interventions move from a focus on activities to a broader program approach that 
focuses  on  results.  It  will  also  help  strengthen  the  monitoring  and  evaluation 
system and the government‘s capacity in results monitoring and reporting.  

Alignment with government system. The fiduciary risk assessment undertaken 
during  project  preparation  suggested  ADB  and  the  development  partners  to  use 
the  government‘s  treasury  system  for  disbursement  and  financial  management. 
The  ADB  loan  and  development  partners‘  funds  will  be  channeled  to  the 
government‘s  treasury  to  finance  PEDP  III  eligible  expenditures,  included  under 
certain  program  budget heads  (PBHs)  in  the government‘s chart  of accounts,  as 
agreed  between  the  government  and  the  development  partners.  The  PBHs  will 
include  total  subsector  expenditures  that  contribute  to  PEDP  III  outcomes,  with 
some  exceptions,  and  will  comprise  both  development  and  nondevelopment 
expenditures.

(iv)

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

Outputs  

9. 
The impact of the PEDP III will be quality education for all children. The outcome of the 
PEDP  III  is  an  efficient,  inclusive,  and  equitable  primary  education  system  delivering  effective 
and  relevant  child-friendly  learning  to  all  of  Bangladesh‘s  children  from  preprimary  through 
grade 5. As the project is to support the PEDP III, the project‘s expected impact and outcome 
will be consistent with the impact and outcome of the PEDP III.  
 
C. 
 
10. 
 The  four  interrelated  broad  results  areas  or  outputs  are  (i)  improved  teaching  and 
learning for all, (ii) reduced disparities and universal access and participation, (iii) decentralized 
and effective organization of the primary education system, and (iv) improved program planning 
and management. The nine DLIs are represented across the four results areas. 
 
Output 1: Improved teaching and learning for all. Output 1 will support (i) initiatives to 
11. 
enhance the performance of all children, (ii) school and classroom based assessment to ensure 
monitoring  and  feedback  on  every  child‘s  learning  outcomes,  (iii)  initiatives  to  strengthen  the 
curriculum and textbooks based on revised competencies, (iv) timely production and distribution 
of quality textbooks to all eligible children, (v) gradual access to information and communication 
technology in education to enhance teaching and learning, and (vi) activities to improve teacher 
education  and  development  to  ensure  that  every  child  learns.  The  output  includes  two  DLIs: 
(i) textbooks  for  each  subject  produced  and  distributed  to  eligible  schools  within  a  month  of 
opening  day,  and  (ii) a  complete  teacher  development  plan  prepared  and  adopted  by  the 
Ministry of Primary and Mass Education (MOPME) and the new diploma in education provided 
to 11,000 teachers annually.   
 
Output  2:  Reduced  disparities  (universal  access  and  participation).  Output  2  will 
12. 
support  (i)  second  chance  and  alternative  education  for  students  that  have  never  enrolled  or 
may have dropped out from formal school; (ii) 1 year preprimary education to children at age 5 
to prepare them for schooling, retention, and completion; (iii) mainstreaming inclusive education 
to address the needs in formal schools of tribal children, ethnic minorities, children with learning 
disabilities, and disabled children; (iv) education in emergencies to prepare disaster-prone areas 
for continuing schooling during emergencies; (v) developing and implementing a communication 
framework and action plan for a social change strategy; (vi) targeting stipends to encourage the 
poorest  families  to  enroll  and  retain  their  children  in  school;  (vii)  school  health  and  school 
feeding to ensure the nutrition and good health of particularly needy children; (viii) an enhanced 
school  physical  environment  based  on  actual  physical  conditions;  and  (ix)  needs-based 
infrastructure  and  furniture  for  conducive  learning.  Two  DLIs  are  included  in  this  output:  (i) 
guidelines  for  preprimary  education  on  the  role  of  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs) 
endorsed by the MOPME, and the coverage of preprimary education expanded; and (ii) needs-
based infrastructure implemented to achieve a pupil to usable classroom ratio of 56:1.

Output  3:  Decentralized  and  effective  organization.  Output  3  will  support                   

13. 
(i)  strengthening  field  level  offices  by  filling  critical  vacancies  with  qualified  and  trained 
personnel;  (ii)  decentralizing  school  management  and  governance  by  deepening  SLIPs  and 
upazila (subdistrict) primary education plans, and introducing district primary education plans to 
plan,  monitor,  and  target  improvements;  (iii)  developing  school  level  leadership  by  enhancing 
the role of head teachers as academic supervisors; (iv) organizational review and strengthening 
field  offices  by  creating  and  filling  new  positions,  and  institutionalizing  a  career  path;  (v) 
improving  the  quality  and  reliability  of  the  grade  5  completion  examination;  (vi) maintaining 
efficient  recruitment  and  deployment  of  teachers;  (vii) strengthening  the  annual  school  census 
by  expanding  its  coverage  to  include  all  types  of  schools;  and  (viii) strengthening  and 
institutionalizing  national  student  assessment.  Four  DLIs  are  included  in  this  output:  (i)  school 
management  committees  and  upazila  education  offices  are  strengthened  to  implement  SLIPs 
and district and upazila primary education plans effectively; (ii) the grade 5 completion exam is 
competency  based  and its  administration  enhanced;  (iii)  new  teachers  are  recruited  based  on 
needs  to  meet  the  pupil–teacher  ratio  of  40:1,  and  using  the  existing  fair  and  transparent 
recruitment system; and (iv) the annual school census coverage will include all types of schools, 
with improvement in the census form, administration, and reporting accuracy and timeliness. 

 
Output  4:  Improved  program  planning  and  management.  Output  4  will  support         

14. 
(i)  MOPME  and  the  Directorate  of  Primary  Education  (DPE)  in  managing  the  PEDP  III,             
(ii) implementation of the PEDP III procurement financial management action plan, (iii) ensuring 
adequate sector financing to meet the requirements of the PEDP III in line with the medium-term 
budgetary  framework,  (iv)  strengthening  monitoring  functions  by  building  on  evidence-based 
planning  and  RBM,  (v)  strengthening  human  resource  development  based  on  needs  and 
revising  the  organizational  development  and  capacity  building  handbook  prepared  under  the 
PEDP II, and (vi) promoting public–private partnership to engage relevant NGOs and the private 
sector  to  support  education  for  all.  One  DLI  is  included  in  this  output:  the primary  education 
budget  aligned  with  the  program  framework  and  consistent  with  the  medium-term  budgetary 
framework, and at least 1.03% of gross domestic product (GDP) allocated to primary education 
every year.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

18. 
The  MOPME  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  the  DPE  will  be  the  key  implementing 
agency. The MOPME will lead overall coordination of the PEDP III. An interministerial program 
steering committee (PSC) will be established, chaired by the secretary of MOPME. Comprising 
representatives  of  key  ministries  and  civil  society,  the  PSC  will  oversee  the  PEDP III  policy 
implementation, review program progress, approve the annual budget, ensure timely decisions 
in  critical  interministerial  policy  and  implementation  issues,  and  provide  operational  guidance. 
The  PSC  will  be  supported  by  a  program  surveillance  unit  (PSU),  headed  by  the  MOPME 
additional  secretary,  and  a  program  support  office.  The  PSU  will  promote  collaboration  and 
coordination  across  ministry  level  agencies,  work  as  a  focal  point  for  development  partner 
support,  organize joint  review  meetings,  and  mobilize  TA  support  to  concerned  agencies.  The 
program  support  office  within  the  PSU  will  serve  as  the  secretariat  of  the  PSC,  will  promote 
regular  communication  and  coordination  with  relevant  ministries,  and  present  a  summary 
progress  report  of  project  implementation  to  the  PSC.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  will  ensure 
smooth fund flow, budget, and fund appropriation. 

19. 
The  DPE  will  (i)  formulate  guidelines  and  plans;  and  (ii)  implement,  supervise,  and 
monitor  the  PEDP  III  through  field  level  agencies.  The  DPE  will  be  restructured  into  eight 
divisions  from  the  existing  six,  with  additional  personnel.  A  position  for  additional  director 
general  will  be  established  to  support  the  DPE  director  general.  The  DPE  will  realign  job 
descriptions  within  each  existing  division  to  ensure  clear  roles  and  responsibilities,  and  to 
mainstream project implementation through the regular system. A technical committee headed

management arrangements are set forth in the project administration manual (PAM).8  

20. 
Procurement  arrangements.  The  ADB  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  goods, 
works,  and  related  services  procured  using  national  competitive  bidding  (NCB).  Such 
procurement will follow the government‘s Public Procurement Act, 2006 and Public Procurement 
Rules,  2008,  with  modifications  and/or  clarifications  to  the  procedures  agreed  between  the 
government,  ADB,  and  other  development  partners,  as  set  out  in  the  PAM  and  procurement 
plan,  acceptable  to  ADB,  and  in  accordance  with  ADB‘s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  Aside  from  ADB,  other  development  partners  will  jointly  finance 
goods,  works,  and  related  services  procured  using  NCB.  ADB  will  not  finance  any  goods  and 
works that will be procured using international competitive bidding as this will follow World Bank 
guidelines.  All  consulting  services  will  be  engaged  using  ADB‘s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The World Bank will not finance consulting 
services. 

21. 
Considering  the  joint  nature  of  the  financing  and  the  eligibility  policies  of  other 
development partners, in particular the World Bank, the procurement process for goods, works 
and  services  using  NCB  will  need  to  be  open  to  firms,  contractors,  and  materials  from  any 
country  eligible  under  ADB  and  other  development  partners.  Accordingly,  ADB‘s  Board  of 
Directors‘  waiver  of  member  country  procurement  eligibility  restrictions  is  sought  to  permit  the 
participation  of  bidders  from  non-ADB  member  countries  and/or  procurement  of  goods  and 
services, including consulting services, from non-ADB member countries.

Disbursement  conditions  and  arrangements.  Funds  will  flow  from  ADB  to  the 
government  consolidated  funds  based  on  withdrawal  applications  submitted  by  the  DPE. 
Expenditures will be made from the treasury via accounting offices under the controller general 
of  accounts  system  on  the  basis  of  the  approved  PEDP  III‘s  annual  budget.  The  statement  of

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic  viability.  The  economic  analysis  for  the  project  assesses  the  benefits  and 
25. 
costs associated with the PEDP III, whereby the project investment is the estimated additional 
cost over and above the currently run PEDP II spending. The benefits are those changes in the 
quantity, quality, and reduction in internal inefficiency of education produced over the period as 
a  result  of  the  PEDP  III.  Benefits  come  from  three  sources:  (i) increased  number  of  primary 
school completers who earn higher wages (relative to non-completers), (ii) increased quality of 
education  resulting  in  a  higher  wage-premium  for  all  primary  school  completers,  and 
(iii) decreased  wastage  of  public  and  private  resources  as  a  result  of  reduced  dropouts  and 
repetitions. Costs include additional program costs (from government and development partner 
sources) and private costs that comprise direct household outlays as well as opportunity costs. 
The PEDP III is expected to implement a wide range of demand- and supply-side interventions 
to improve access, equity, and efficiency. At the same time, it aims at enhancing the quality of 
schooling  through  improved  student,  school,  and  teacher-level  subprograms  as  well  as  some 
overriding  policy  and  institutional  reforms.  The  internal  rate  of  return  associated  with  this  net 
present value is 24% for a 5-year program, which suggests that the PEDP III is expected to be a 
very sound investment. 

26. 
Fiscal  sustainability.  The  long-term  sustainability  of  the  PEDP  III  will  depend  on  two 
factors:  (i)  adequate  budget  to  the  MOPME  to  cover  estimated  investments  as  per  the  fiscal 
projection  for  GDP  growth  scenarios,  and  (ii)  improvements  in  quality  and  efficiency  as 
envisaged.  The  NEP  proposes  a  significant  increase  in  government  budget  allocation  to  the 
education sector (up to 6% of GDP from 2.3% in 2010-2011), confirming the urgency to ensure 
higher allocations to the education sector. Given the positive outlook for GDP growth, the NEP‘s 
call for a higher allocation, and a minimum allocation of 1.03% of GDP to  the MOPME budget

PEDP II; (ii) the projected incremental costs from the PEDP III (annual recurrent, short cyclical

major  synergies:  (i) without  development  partners‘  funds,  government  funds  would  be

order not to lose development partners‘ funds to sustain priority reforms.

Poverty and Social 

Positive effects of public investment in education and health, and NGOs‘ contribution in 
28. 
economic  and  social  empowerment  activities,  have  contributed  to  significant  improvement  in 
poverty  reduction  in  the  1990s  and  2000s.  Government  subsidies  of  about  56%  on  primary 
education  benefit  the  poor—about  50%  of  the  population—but  this  is  inadequate  since  poor 
segments  of  the  population  are  systematically  lagging  in  enrolment  and  primary  cycle 
completion. They cannot afford the (direct and indirect) expenses of primary schooling. The 6% 
of  school-age  children  not  yet  enrolled  in  primary  education  are  children  from  extremely  poor 
families,  children  from  women-headed  households,  working  children,  street  children,  children 
with  special  needs,  children  from  minority  ethnic  and  language  groups,  and  children  from 
remote or inaccessible areas. Building on PEDP II experience, the PEDP III has harmonized the 
strategies  and  action  plans  developed  for  tribal,  vulnerable,  and  special  needs  children,  and 
gender,  under the  inclusive education  action  plan. This  will  support  expansion  of  a  conditional 
stipend  program,  supply  of  free  textbooks,  tuition  waivers,  expansion  of  the  school  meal 
program, provision of second chance education, inclusive education, and quality improvements.

D. 

Safeguards 

30. 
Environment.  The  project  is  environment  category  B.  A  common  harmonized 
environmental  management  framework  has  been  prepared.  The  PEDP  III,  based  on  needs 
assessment and agreed criteria, will support construction of new schools and dormitories; repair 
and  maintenance  of  existing  schools;  and  provision  of  safe  drinking  water,  sanitation  and 
drainage  facilities.  With  adequate  arrangements  for  site  selection,  design,  construction,  and 
operation and maintenance, the PEDP III is not expected to create any significant or long-term 
adverse  environmental  impact.  Consistent  with  government  and  ADB  policy,  the  Local 
Government  and  Engineering  Department  will  monitor  implementation  of  the  environment 
management  framework  semiannually.  The  department  has  the  capacity  to  implement  the 
framework.  It  will  prepare  and  disclose  periodic  monitoring  reports  that  describe  progress  on 
implementation of the framework, and compliance issues and corrective actions, if any.   

31. 
Resettlement.  The  project  is  category  B for  involuntary  resettlement.  Social  safeguard 
issues  may  arise  from  the  extension  of  existing  and  creation  of  new  physical  facilities. 
Bangladesh‘s  schools  are  generally  established  on  designated  government-owned  land,  free 
from  other  temporary  or  permanent  use.  The  PEDP II  did  not  trigger  the  Involuntary 
Resettlement  Policy  (1995)  because  beneficiary  communities  provided  lands,  where  needed. 
Under the PEDP III, local communities  are expected to continue to contribute land. Consistent 
with government  and  ADB  policy,  a  harmonized  resettlement  framework  has  been  prepared—

proportion  of  the  country‘s  small  indigenous  population.  The  rest  are  dispersed  in  the  plains 
districts  of  greater  Sylhet,  Mymensingh,  and  the  north  and  southwest  regions,  where  they

general  and  physical  works  in  particular  do  not  adversely  affect  indigenous  peoples,  and  that 
they receive culturally compatible social and economic benefits.
